thread.title: Still no Nobel for Newark's Philip Roth; literature prize goes to Belarussian
thread.title_full: Still no Nobel for Newark's Philip Roth; literature prize goes to Belarussian | NJ.com

author: Vicki Hyman | NJ Advance Media for NJ.com
title: Still no Nobel for Newark's Philip Roth; literature prize goes to Belarussian
text:
Belarussian journalist and writer Svetlana Alexievich has won the Nobel Prize in Literature for her work chronicling the suffering of ordinary people living through war and other manmade disasters — making New Jersey's own Philip Roth , 82 and long a contender for the award bestowed only to living authors, an also-ran again.
The Newark native , now retired from letters , has won almost every major prize in fiction, including the National Book Award twice (the first at age 26 for his first novel "Goodbye, Columbus"), the National Book Critics Circle award twice, the PEN/Faulkner Award three times, and the Pulitzer Prize in 1998 for "American Pastoral," one of his novels featuring his literary alter-ego Nathan Zuckerman.
The author's native Weequhaic neighborhood, a firmly middle-class Jewish enclave when he was growing up in Newark in the 1940s, serves as the score for many of his works.
The Nobel Prize in Literature has not been won by an American since 1993, when it was awarded to Toni Morrison , the retired Princeton professor and author of "The Bluest Eye," "Song of Solomon" and "Beloved." London bookmakers gave good odds this year to Alexievich and Roth, as well as other perennial contenders for the prize — Haruki Murakami of Japan, Ngugi Wa Thiong'o of Kenya and another retired Princeton professor and novelist, Joyce Carol Oates .
